titleStmt.title: Rowley, William, 1585?-1642? : : All's lost by lust (1633)

editionStmt.p: This electronic version was produced at the Centre for Literary and Linguistic Computing at the University of Newcastle by keyboarding from a microfilm printout of an early printed version. It was originally in a format devised in the Centre, with reference panels at the beginning of each line, known as "LILAC". It was subsequently converted by an automated process to a TEI XML format. It lacks the speaker tags provided in the copytext. Contractions and variant spellings of function words have been silently regularised. The text thus lacks information about the original forms of many words and expressions.

publicationStmt.publisher: William Rowley, 1585?-1642? (1585?-1626) A Tragedy called All's Lost by Lvst. Written by William Rowley. Divers times Acted by the Lady Elizabeths Servants. And now lately by her Maiesties Servants, with great applause, at the Phoenix in Drury Lane London Printed by Thomas Harper 1633

sourceDesc.p: Play details All's lost by lust. Genre: Tragedy. Date first published: 1633. Date first performed: 1619-1620 ?

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

stage.l: ROderigo, King of Spaine, being deeply
by private solicitations and gifts, tried to win
her to his embraces; but they not prevailing, he
resolves to enjoy her by force: whilst he fails in
of better fortunes than condition) is his Pilot,
steering his wickedness on. To help which with
wind and weather, Mulymumen, King of Barbary,
with an Army of 60000. Moors, is ready
to cross into Spaine, to invade Roderigo,
who no way frighted, but laying hold on this occasion,
sends Iulianus as General against the African,
and by his two evil Spirits, Lothario and
Malæna) gets access to the Lady in her Fathers
absence, but their Engines breaking, he ravishes
her. The Dove being thus ruffled, is delivered
out of one Falcons Talons, to the gripe of another:
Lothario is made her Keeper, whom Iacynta one
day finding fast asleep, takes the keys of the Castle
from him, and flies to her Father in the Camp;
who hearing the story of the Reposure, joins
with those Spanish Lords in his Army, to be revenged
on the Tyrant: To hasten this vengeance,
the African is taken prisoner, and again set at
liberty, with condition that he shall Rally all his
scattered Troops, and then those two Armies being
incorporated in one, to drive Roderigo out
of his Kingdom, and to enthrone the Moore there.
Mulymumen so likes the ravished Lady, that
he begs her of her Father to be his: but Roderigo
flying into Biscany, and the African Lord of
all, is scorned by Iacynta, who in revenge, calls
for Iulianus (her Father) commanding his eyes
to be put out, and her tongue to be cut out, and so
to lead him; In the end, the Barbarian to shorten
Iulianus his misery, gives him a weapon, the
Moore hath another, with intent to run full-butt
at one another, much entreaty being made to let
Iacynta die nobly, it is promised, and then they both
being ready to run, the Moore snatches Iacynta
before him, and so the Father kills his own Daughter,
and is presently by the Moore slain himself.
Antonio marries Margaretta, fair, but low
in fortunes, and coming to these wars, falls in
love with Dionysia, daughter to Alonzo, but
the women come to tragical ends, and Antonio
for upbraiding Iulianus with selling his King
and Country to the Moore, is by Iulianus slain.

sp.l: Prologue.
THus from the Poet am I bid to say,
He knows what Judges sit to doom each Play,
(The ever-curious Critic, or the wise)
The one with squint, the other with sun-like eyes,
Shoots through each Scæne: the one cries all things down,
The other hides strangers faults close as his own,
Alas! Those who out of customs come to gear,
(Sung the full quire of the nine Muses here)
So carping, not from wit, but apish spite,
And feathered ignorance, that our Poet does slight.
It is not a gay suit, or distorted face,
Can beat his merit off, which has won grace
In the full Theatre, nor can now fear
The teeth of any snaky whisperer:
But to the white, and sweet unclouded brow,
(The heaven where true worth moves) our Poet does bow;
Patrons of Arts, and Pilots to the Stage,
Who guide it (through all tempests) from the rage
Of envious whirlwinds. O do you but steer
His Muse this day, and bring her to the wished shore,
You are those Delphic powers, whom she will adore.

stage.l: Enter Rodericke, King of Spaine, Lothario, Medina, Iulianus,

sp.l: GIve leave: Lothario.
My Sovereign.
The news in brief: how replies
Iacinta?
Will she be woman? will she meet our
With an alternate roundure? will she do?
Nothing to the purpose my Liege, cold as Aquarius,
There she was born, and there she still remains;
I cannot move her to enter into Pisces, I
Laid the flesh to her too, and the delights thereof, she leans
Another way, and talks all of the spirit, I
Frighted her with spirits too, but all would not do:
She drew her knife, pointed it to her breast, swore
She would do something, but women's tongues are
Sometimes longer than their arms.
Enough, we have bethought another way.
This wooing application is too mild,
It is better trust the mercy of a storm.
To haste our way, than to be calmed for ever,
Short of the wished haven:
Now draw near, you told us of a hot invasion,
The barbarous and tawny Affricans,
Intend upon our confines.
True, my Liege.
Full threescore thousand are descried in Arms,
Ready to pass the Straights of Gibraltar,
Whose watery divisions, their Affricke bounds
From our Christian Europe in Granado,
And Audalusia; they spread and flourish
Their silver moons, led as it is supposed,
By some blind guide, some Saintish Infidel,
That prophesies subjection of our Spaine,
Unto the Moors.
They would deter us with their swarthy looks;
Were they the same to their similitude,
Sooty as the inhabitants of hell,
Whom they nearest figure: cold fear should fly
From us as distant as they are from beauty:
They come to sacrifice their bloods to us,
If that be red, a mare rubrum,
We will make so high to quench their silver moons;
And on their carcasses an Isthmus make
To pass their straits again, and forage there.
Your forward valour speaks you majestical,
But my dread Liege, does not your treasury
Grow thin and empty? so long have you held
A champion resolution against the Turk,
That Spaine is wasted in her noble strength,
On which presuming, it is to be supposed
The Moore is thus encouraged.
And yet we undaunted Iulianus, our treasury is
A mine unsearched, we have a Castle
Supposed enchanted, we will break the magic,
If spells there be, ope the forbidden doors
Which twenty of our predecessors have refused,
But added each a lock to guard it more.
Rather than our Soldiers shall want pay
To fight our battles nobly.
O my Lord, that is a dangerous secret, only known
To such as can divine futurities.
And they with fearful prophesies predict
Fatal events to Spaine, when that shall be
Broke up by violence; till fate hath run
Her own wasting period; which outstayed
Auspiciously they promise, that wreathes are kept
In the fore-dooming Court of destiny,
To bind us ever in a happy conquest.
Tut, fear frights us not, nor shall hope fool us:
If need provoke, we will dig supply through hell
And her enchantments. Who can prefix us
A time to see these incantations loosed?
Perhaps it will stay ten generations more,
When our blood royal may want succession,
If not, what boots it us (lost in our dust
And memory 500. years) that then this hidden
Work shall be, tush, the weakness of our predecessors
Shall not fright us, all is not deadly,
That looks dangerous.
I wish no life to see that day.
Nor I, so many Kings have feared that destiny.
Lord Iulianus, we commit to you
The charge of this great work against the Moors,
With title of Lord General, as you please,
Order this high affair; call to the field
An equal Army against those Affricans,
The bold and hardiest soldiers of our kingdom.
Scourge back again those half-naked infidels
Into their sun-burnt Climate; in thy heart
Be loyalty and courage, strength in thine arm:
With christian valour strike the heathens dead,
And for thy triumph, bring the Mulyes head.
This honour which your Majesty has given me,
Though better it might fit another's wearing,
Of abler limbs, where time has not defaced,
Nor half so many winters quenched his blood,
As a new spring it hath revived again
This Autumn of my years, there is but one care
I leave behind me within the Court of Spaine,
My poor Iacinta mine, and only mine;
May she here thrive in honour, and in favours,
And I shall meet her with a victory,
(Heaven put before) as shall endow us both
In your high esteem.
That shall be our care noble Iulianus, to see her safe,
We love Iacinta more than you must know,
And for her sake we do remove you hence,
You may thank your daughter for this honour Sir,
If you knew our purpose.
I understand all this, whilst he wars abroad, his
Daughter must skirmish at home; Venus is in conjunction
With Mercury, wit and lechery are both in labour
At once alas poor maidenhead, thou art cast i'faith,
And must to execution; virginity hadst thou been
Moulded in my compass, thou hadst scaped this pitfall.
On, to thy charge, prosper in thy high deeds;
Who aims at honour noble, nobly speeds.
My heart and tongue, thus sentence to my fate,
In honour thrive, in baseness ruinate.
All help him on his speed: Lothario.

stage.l: Exeunt omnes nisi Rod. and Loth.

sp.l: Have we not finely moulded our design?
Times ancient bawd, opportunity attends us now,
And yet our flaming blood will scarce give leave
To opportunity.
I told your highness of a second bawd to time, and yet
Not times second neither, for time
A thing real, not a dumb moral, as time itself
Is, but a speaking thing, and one that speaks
Effectually; one that has wracked more maiden-heads
In Spaine, than she has years upon her reverent brows,
And yet she writes odd of threescore, an odd wench it is.
Thou namest her to me.
Malena.
And hast instructed her?
I have prepared her fit for instruction my Liege; she
Waits her further confirmation from your Highness:
O every soldier has a double heart, when the King is in field.
Call her
By her right name; bawd, where art thou bawd?
We will pluck this apple from the Hesperides.
If Words will serve, if not, by rapines force;
This is the thing I told your Highness of.
A reverent one it is, and may be called schoolmistress
of her sex; if Apelles had ever pictured forth experience,
here might he take his pattern.
Indeed my Liege, I have been the pattern that a great
Many has taken out pictures by. I confess I have
Been a greater friend to the Hospitals, than the Nunneries,
And I think it was the greater chastity, because
They are the poorer, and more wretched places.
The very ipsissima of her sex, my Liege, as old as
She is, I will undertake she shall wrestle a fall
With the strongest Virgin in Spaine, and throw her down too.
Thou must be my Lawyer (I will see thee well,)
And at the Bar of beauty plead a cause,
Which whether right or wrong, must needs be mine.
Indeed in rightful causes, weak Lawyers will
Serve turn, but the wrong had need have
The best Orators; I am but a weak vessel, you
Know my Liege.
She will hold out I warrant, hark you my Liege,
This vessel is not hollow yet, it does not sound,
There is metal in her, there is sack in this Tun,
That has eaten up a great deal of dead
Flesh in her time, lights, longs and bad livers.
Come, come, you must not plead an insufficiency.
I will do my best my Lord.
Tush, in malo consilio fœmina vincunt viros.
Does he not abuse me my Liege?
Not at all, he says women overcome men in
Giving counsel.
Is there not a faulty word amongst them?
Thou art able to corrupt any good sense, with bad construction:
I say fœmina vincunt that is, quasi vincere cunctos,
Overcomes all men.
Go to, go to, there is a broad word amongst them,
vincunt Quotha, is it spoke with a K, or a C? but in plain
Language I will do my best, if she be of my sex, I
Will show her the end of her function, men follow
The traditions of their forefathers, so should
Women follow the trades of their fore-mothers.
I see thou hast persuasive oratory.
Here is juice of liquorish, good for thy voice,
Speak freely, and effectually.
I will speak the words that have overthrown a
Hundred in my time.
I was within compass then.
Let me have access to her, if she be flesh and blood,
I will move her, I will not leave her till I turn her to a stone.
Unite your forces both, conquer in love,
I will reward as for a victory
Purchased with blood from my worst enemy:
Effect, for ill things have their effects we see
Prosper, we will call it a prosperity:
You will bring me to the place and party?
Prepared with all advantage. I will assist thee, thou
Destroyer of maiden-heads.
Your passions err my Lord, did you foresee
What may ensue, folly begets danger,
Nay oft, their full effects, destruction,
You would not clothe the nobleness of your blood
In such base weeds, she is a beggar you dote on.
Thou hast spoke the worst thy malice can invent,
A beggar sayst? and better being so,
If a small Star could overshine the Sun,
And show his brightness in the solstice,
Should it be blamed or praised? the feeble Vine
Brings forth sweet fruits, whilst the Cedars is barren,
Beggar is she, I will poise her graces with it,
And see how many infinities she will pull
The balance down, and yet that poverty
A goodness disesteemed, she is fair,
Modest, lovely, wise, virtuous.
Nay, if you dote, I will waste no more good counsel,
And what is her dower Sir?
Infinities, I named them to thee.
O she is fair, a fair dowry.
Chaste and virtuous.
Those are jewels indeed, but they will yield little.
They are not things of prise, they are far off,
And dear, yet Ladies send not for them.
May not a league be taken for a time?
Defer this hasty match, you have employment
As a Soldier, the King has given you charge,
Approve your champion valour in the field,
If that remove not this domestic trouble,
Retire upon your Venus.
I will prevent that venom,
This night I will be married to my sweet,
And then her memory enjoyed, shall strengthen
Mine arms against my foe, which else would droop,
Suspecting of her loss, I fear it now;
What eye can look upon her, but is captived
In the enchanted prison of her eyes.
Why you will be jealous in your absence then?
Away, away, thou dost forget her virtues
Faster than I can name them, she is chastity
Itself, and when a Shrine shall be set up
Unto that Saint, it shall be built upon
The marble that shall cover her.
Here comes the General.
No more, no more, thy fears are all follies, my Iacinta
I must not leave you thus.
Antonio? what unplumed? you are a Soldier sir,
And Soldiers should be forward; look ye
I have bright steel for the black Affricans;
I tell you Sir, I went not with more joy
Unto my maiden Bride, that Hymen night,
From whence I fetched this jewel of my heart,
Than now I do unto my second nuptials,
O it is a gallant Mistress, an old man
Is young again at sight of her.
Worthy Sir, your leading valour will centuple the hearts
Of all your followers, when set you forward?
Tush, we limit time to her best haste,
Three days will be the most, the longer stay
Looses the more advantage.
We shall be ready to attend your honour,
Hymen, this night I vow to thee, Mars be my
Morrows Saint.
Here were a Saint fitting your orisons.
Blasphemy, speak that no more, the beggar,
(If you will so profane to speak her so)
Is gold refined, compared unto this rubbish,
Diamond to Marble, my noble Lord
We will leave you to hasten our attendance on you.
Farewell Antonio.
I am in haste too, my preparations call me.
I call too, I beseech you hear me.
Thou art a clog to me,
Methinks thou shouldest be reading over new fashions,
Conferring with your Tire-woman for fair dressings,
Your Jeweller has new devices for ye,
Fine labels for your ears, bracelets for wrists,
Such as will illustrate your white hand,
These are all Peddlers ware to me, Iacinta,
I am for Corselets, Helmets, Bills, Bows, and Pikes,
The thundering Guns, Trumpets tan tara,
The rattling sheepskin, and the whistling Fife:
What Music is this to your ears? ha, farewell,
Farewell, and heaven bless thee.
Good heaven, how slightly
You over-run my fears, you go to meet
With a full power, an armed foe abroad,
And leave me single to an enemy
That hath both power and will to ruin me.
It is treason, that thou speakest, and by the Saint
Of Spaine, mend it, or I will discover thee:
Wrong my dread Liege, my King, my Sovereign,
To say that he should dote upon your face,
Away, away, it is but your beauties pride,
So to belie itself thou art not fair,
Thou hast no eye to attract Majesty,
To look upon it; say he speak love to thee,
It was but to try thee, perhaps it was my consent,
Will you enquire the hidden hearts of Kings?
He would not wrong thee for his kingdoms wealth,
Even for my sake, away you wanton fool.
There has been ravishers, remember Tarquin.
There has been chaste Ladies, remember Lucres:
I will hear no more, my time and haste hath bard me,
My blessing take, heaven and that shall guard thee.
You leave me in a tempest, heaven guide my fate,
O let me sink ere I be captivate.
I do not like this match, this gay out-side
Is cloth of gold, within a ragged lining.
O poor comparison father, do they use to line
cloth of gold with cloth of gold; no, but with fine, gentle,
and easy linings, and such my sister may be, for though I say
it that should not say it, my sister has a good face, a white
neck, and a dainty hand, and that may serve for lining
for the best cloth of gold in all Spaine.
Cedars and shrubs cannot grow up together.
Away, away, speak not so like a Wood monger, I will
Put you down with a caparison now, do we not use
To graft sweet apples upon crab-tree stocks, do we
Not use to inoculate your Malicatoon upon a Gooseberry?
Such is my sisters case now, say that the noble man
Would inoculate his Lordship upon my sisters yeomandry,
What hurt were in this? would it grieve you to be a
Lords brother, or this old woman to have her Lady
Daughter to ask, Granam, how do you, will you ride
Abroad in your Crotch, or your embroidered side-saddle?
Aye, thou talkest wildly boy, yet errest not much
In my conceit, be content man, and add as meet it is,
Joy to content, your daughter shall be made a happy woman
By a noble marriage.
Happy sayst thou? o it is as distant as the Moon from earth,
And has the like effects, it changes oft,
So with a silver brow, greatness looks on us
Promising and lovely, but once grown full,
It brings swelling billows to overwhelm us.
Pray father talk no more of the moon, but of your son,
Not myself that am your son and heir, but of your
Son-in-law that shall be, my noble L. Antonio Lord of
Barcelona, and his noble Lady my sister, that shall be.
It will well become her, what arms shall I give to
make her gentle by?
Those we can buy of the Heralds, you know she
Has cried Oranges the most of her time here in Civil,
Now a fine Orange for her crest, with Civility
Written round about it would speak wondrous well,
Than a Capon in a Scutcheon with a gizzard
Under his left arm, with his spurs upon his heels
Riding upon a Leman.
Away, away
Thy talk is impertinent, what should a Capon
Do with a Leman?
Aye, you say well Father there indeed,
A Capon desires no Leman, and therefore
We will hope of both that neither the Lord
Prove himself a Capon, nor my sister a Leman.
Aye, this thou touchest by a forced figure,
The perfect sense of all, thence grows my fear:
This love was first conceived, and born in lust
How long has he laid an unlawful siege
Against her Virgin honour, which had she yielded,
And been so lemoned, she never had been proffered
The style of wife.
Peace, see they come.
Aye marry, here is a Lady now will wear her own hair.
Nay now no further protestations,
You have said enough to make me new, or ruin me,
And this my spirit, bids me prophesy
If you repent, as love might be overfated
In its best desires; and any cross event
Should fall upon this your unequal choice,
Yours is the crime, your handmaid must be blameless,
Since you have sought what I have not desired,
And yet, you may avoid the fatal doom
(If any such there be) by throwing back
Your achieved vassal.
Teach me no error.
I will not learn it, sweetest, if you do.
Speak nothing now but of those holy rites
Whose sacred hands must guide us to the path
Of your desired Joys.
Here is all the bar;
When these have given consent I am your own.
It shall be done in this acknowledgement.
Father and mother let me but call you so.
And brother eke also.
Yes brother too,
By this I claim them all, your daughter makes
Me your son, and yours.
And my brother.
I will not forget that neither.
If you do, I will forget to call your Lady Sister.
Sir, I have questioned all the will in me,
And find it now resolved unto your wish.
You have my good will too brother.
Mine is wrought out through rocks of doubt and fear,
She is your own, I send her pilot-like
Into an Argosy beyond her steerage.
I will hand the helm with her, and there abide
Safety, or drowning.
She will be hated when the disdainful brows
Of noble greatness shall be shot against her,
The scorns and shouts she shall endure will be
Far less content, than is the humble quiet she enjoys.
All those I will rebuke, and if she blush,
The beauty then will check their painted cheeks
With a rebounding shame upon themselves.
Let not more obstacles be mentioned,
Only let privacy protect us yet
Although we scant the full solemnity
Due to thy wishes, Hymen which afterwards
Shall dare the largest blazon.
Call it mine Sir,
And then the smallest ceremony may serve.
All wants, are only wanting unto you
To give your greatness the due ornaments.
Shall your kind pains provide us of a Priest,
Whom my instructions shall direct you to.
Shall I? why who am I pray?
Yes, good brother do.
O you teach me sweet; yes good brother do.
O as a brother I will, I perceive these great men
Are somewhat forgetful of their poor kindred.
A Fryer in Saint Austins Monastery
Ask for one Benedicke, my commends to him
Will bring him with thee, he is prepared for it.
I will be the Clarke myself for the groat sake,
Which you know will arise out of the two and twenty.
Tush, I will treble that wages.
Nothing grieves me but this wedding will be so still born
We shall have no dancing at it, but I will foot it
To the Priest howsoever, Fala, la, la, la:
However the kings employment in the wars
Calls on my person, I shall leave behind
Myself in thee, and bear myself along
In thy sweet memory.
O Sir, you speak of swift divorce.
Relish to joy, a breathing from our pleasures.
Come, come, true love shall tie two hearts in one.
O happy proof.
COme old reverence, if ever thou hadst music
in thee,
To enchant a maidenhead, now strike up.
You play well
On the Pandora, Sir I wonder your skill
Fails to make her dance after it.
Tush, I give thee
The precedence, wire strings will not do it, it must be
A wind instrument that is governed with stopping of holes,
Which thou playest well on, my old Viol de gamb,
Come, thou shalt have reward.
And what pay have you for pandership,
Little or nothing, it comes short of the bawd always.
A bawd, why what is a bawd, pander?
Why bawd, I will tell thee what a bawd is.
Then pander I will tell thee, what a pander is.
A bawd is a thing that when the devil plays at maw,
He turns up trump, because she is a help.
But the pander playing with the devil robs the bawd
To make his hand the stronger, and the cards being
The devils, he makes out a little heart (and that is all
He has) into the stock.
The devil vies it with the bawd.
The pander being drunk sees the devil.
The devil plays on, and looses the bawd.
And takes away the knave (which is the pander)
With his five finger.
And fearing he has not tricks enough
Gives up his dealing to the bawd,
so they shuffle again.
Enough of this game.
Well, the maidenhead is
In this enchanted Castle, thou must blow up,
Give fire old Linstocke, I confess I am repulsed in the van;
If thou failest too the king comes with a murdering piece
In the rear, o it is a royal service.
Well, leave it to me Sir.
She, she sallies upon thee, Asmotheus, Carothus, and
all the fiends of the flesh
Stand at thine elbow.
Bless ye fair Virgin:
From your age with a virgin Epitaph, if you
No better be than I esteem you.
It were pity
Indeed you should be a virgin to my age
Sweet beauty, you would be like a garment long laid by,
And out of fashion, which though new, would not be worth a wearing:
Is that your companion
Parted with you?
No companion Lady,
But a friend of mine, as I hope he is of yours.
You are both naught then, and neither friends of mine,
But here you have me prisoner in your power
If you have aught to speak to me out with it.
You are beloved Lady, and which is more,
Yea most,
Of a king beloved.
A good induction:
And all this I may deserve being a loyal subject.
Your loyalty may be mixed with his royalty,
If you will be ruled, understand, kings are not common things,
Nor are their actions common, all things are
Proper, and peculiar unto them, so Ladies
Whom they love, are commonly proper Ladies, who being
Proper, cannot be counted common.
It is all
My pride, I will be accounted proper.
Only to a king.
And common to all the world besides,
That were gross.
You wrest my meaning virgin, I would not have you be
A virgin, is not that your meaning?
Now you come to me;
It is true: For what is a virgin? knew you as much
As I you would never be a virgin.
I dare swear I should not.
A virgin? why it is as much as to say because
You were born a child you should ever be so;
This were ridiculous. Virginity,
Why it is a Jewel kept in a Casket,
Which never opened,
as good you never had it;
Shall musk be always kept in the Cod, how shall
The sweetness be tasted then? Virginity is
Like a false friend to you, which indeed is better lost than kept.
Out shame of women, thou the falsest art,
Be lost for ever looking on my face,
Or lose those instruments thou lookest withal,
Immodesties in men are venial,
When women rebel against their weaker selves.
Out hag, turn thee into some other shape,
Or I shall curse myself for being one
Of thy bad sex.
Nay, I have done with you Lady,
If Flags of truce will not serve, you must look
For defiance, and here he comes that brings it with him.
All powers of goodness guard me.
Speak, is she pliant?
Stubborn as an Elephants leg, no bending in her,
You know what you have to do my Liege, trees that
Will not yield their fruit by gentle shaking, must
Be climbed, and have it pulled by violence.
Give leave.
I would she would give leave as soon
As I, you should not be troubled to ask a duty
From me, I would fall at your feet my Liege.
Why turn you from us Lady?
O my Liege,
I turn not from your face, but from your power,
You bring a frown, I dare not look upon.
Your thoughts instruct you ill, I do not frown,
But smile upon you.
I crave your pardon, and bend
My knee, your true obedient servant, my life
I will lay an offering at your feet, what more
Would you from your humble vassal?
Nothing so much,
But for less than either, thy love fair virgin.
Keeping this name, you have it ever.
What name?
A virgin, you have my prayers daily to heaven
For your long sovereignties, your honours health and victories.
It is good, and will you deny yourself, what you wish
From others? I would achieve a victory from you.
Sir, I am not your foe.
Concluded well,
Approve yourself a friend, the war is love,
Wherein we two must strive make it no war,
But yield it freely.
It is not love you seek;
But an Antipathy as dissonant
As heaven and hell, the music of the spheres.
Compared with gnashings, and the howls below.
Can lust be called love, then let men seek hell,
For there that fiery deity doth dwell.
We come not to dispute of good, and bad,
Do as your sex has done, taste what is forbid,
And then distinguish of the difference,
I come not now to war with eloquence,
Those treaties are all past, if you embrace
Our proffered love, we will pray; or call it lust,
If not, we speak a king to you, you must:
Will you be a Ravisher?
Call it as you please,
We have a burning fever, and the disease
You must lay balsam to.
Poison be it,
A serpentine, and deadly aconite,
Never survive to know what you have done,
But perish in the deed, or ere begun.
These blasts are Zephyr's breath, a gentle gale
When it blows high.
Then let my tears prevail.
The sacrifice of fools, the proverbs scorn,
None pities women's tears, but Idiots born.
Remember what my Father does for you,
He is gone to brandish against your enemies,
He is fetching you honour home; while at home
You will dishonour him.
My purpose it was,
To send him forth the better to achieve
My conquest here.
Tyrannous unkingly.
Tush, I have no ears.
He will be revenged;
Pity, nor future fears.
Help, help, some good hand help:
There is none within thy call.
Heaven hears.
Tush, it is far off.
See heaven, a wicked king, lust stains his Crown,
Or strike me dead, or throw a vengeance down.
Tush heaven is deaf, and hell laughs at thy cry.
Be cursed in the act, and cursed die.
I will stop the rest within thee.
Not the messenger returned from the Castle
With answer from Alonzo?
See my Lord, they come together.
Noble Iulianus, the dignity of general
You wear, be with your valour individual,
Till we have made it triple by our conquests,
Then let that threefold one, impale your brows,
And bear it to king Roderique in triumph.
Worthy Alonzo you must help your wishes
Ere they can take effect, your approved arm
Will be a good assistant, but I pray Sir,
How have you kept your Castle so unbruised?
The foe not far distant, have you not taken
Nor given? no sallying forth, no buffeting?
My Lord, we have been yet as quiet as in league,
Which makes me guess their number is not full,
They have not yet, unless with grim aspects
So much as frighted this my tender daughter.
Tender father, I pray let not your pity disparage me,
I have seen a sword shipped out stark naked in my time,
And never squeaked; Do you think a Sarazius head,
Or a Blackamoors face can affright me, let me then
Be afraid of every chimney sweeper.
Good spirit i'faith;
Even such a soldier have I left behind,
I had much ado to keep her from the field;
Poor Iacinta, had I known such a sworn sister for her
I should almost have given her leave.
I will tell you Sir,
Were there a band of buskined Amazons
That would tuck up their skirts, and strike indeed
My girl should wear bright Menalippaes belt
She should be foremost; and I will venture her.
Is she such a striker, my Lord?
All at head,
Nowhere else, believe me Sir,
we hold it base
To strike below the waist.
You fight high Lady:
So she does at heart I think.
So, so, to her bachelors,
Antonio, Lazarello, Medina; Come Alonzo,
You and I must treat more seriously upon our war intendments.
The general wrongs you to call you bachelor, Antonio.
Would he did not wrong me.
Have not you a Cardiac
A heart fever now, ha? Do you think there is
A Phoenix now, is there but one good face
In the world?
I see nothing in her face,
Prithee attempt to make her
speak again.
Her tongue? nay if you like her tongue, you must needs
Like her tail, for the one utters the other: Lady
What would you give now for Moors heads by the dozen?
I would buy by the score Sir.
And what a score then?
Chalk is best for the score, every alewife knows that.
You talk of chalk, and I of cheese.
He is in the first dish, pray take him away here.
I have not done yet, will you buy any ware of me?
What? proffered ware? foh.
Give over, thou wilt be soiled else.
Why, here is a wench now, I had rather lie with her
Wit, than with the best piece of flesh in Christendom,
I could beget young Mercuries on her, with
The very conceit: would you had had a good pair
Of eyes in your head.
They are false glasses, and will
Deceive me.
My Lords to arms, the foe discovered,
Marching amain upon you.
We are in readiness, our Council is broke,
Advice must be all blows, Lady to your hold,
And at advantage, see what these youths will do;
To gain your love, nobly for Spaine speak drum,
And if they call, answer for us, they come.

stage.l: Alarum. Enter Mully Mumen King of the Moores.

sp.l: Descend thy sphere, thou burning Deity,
Haste from our shame, go blushing to thy bed;
Thy sons we are, thou everlasting ball,
Yet never shamed these our impressive brows
Till now; we that are stamped with thine own seal,
Which the whole ocean cannot wash away:
Shall those cold ague cheeks that nature moulds
Within her winter shop, those smooth white skins,
That with a palsy hand she paints the limbs,
Make us recoil.
Great Mullymumen haste,
Either give heart to our retiring troops
By a fresh onset, or haste to safety by
Flight and baseness: Bomizaverian is slain.
Where is our brother Mahu Mahomet?
Rounded with danger,
Where he behaves himself nobly Haldillinbaiday,
Enafer, and five Alchaidas more are gone
Up to his rescue, and if not more he dies,
Or is captived.
We will partake either or both with him,
They are both noble; but too basely fly
Is to preserve life, and let honour die.
Fall then my flesh, so there survive my name,
Who flies from honour, follows after shame.

stage.l: Alarum. Enter Iulianus, Antonio, and Alonzo.

sp.l: Antonio, now by the Saint of Spaine
You have made yourself remarkable today,
Valour, exceeding valour, was not looked for
Which you have shown today.
So nobly Sir, that I could wish my daughter
Were in love with you, and your virtues; would you
Requite it, her dowry should be 50 thousand crowns.
More than I ever meant it.
O heart, thou speakest too late,
My Lords your praises, and your noble wishes
Makes me esteem myself behindhand with fame
Here is yet more work to do.
One Mully we have taken.
If Mumen fly not, he is his fellow-captive.
There my new fortunes shall their honour prove,
Then farewell war, next we will war fair with love.
Medina, post to king Rodorique, do thus and thus.
Tell our royal Master what work we have done him
You see and know, and it needs no relation,
Here are royal prisoners.
How will you use us?
As in captivity we wish ourselves.
May we not be ransomed?
As from the king
We shall receive: as his pleasure returns us,
Meantime you shall have cause to blame
Your fortunes, not your conquerors, where is Antonio
The best deserver of this days honour.
Retired to his tent.
Not wounded, is he?
No my Lord, but weary.
So we are all,
Now we have time to rest, and get new breath,
We conquer to the life, and not the death.

stage.l: Enter Antonio reading a letter, Lazarello.

sp.l: Now Antonio, where is Margaretta now?
Here.
Whose that in your hand then?
I know not, look, it is gone.
Fie, you will take it up again; come, come, stoop,
This is Dionisiaes character; a hand worth your heart,
Peruse it better, so, so, it is well:
Ladies fair hands must not be rejected so;
I did foresee this dangerous relapse,
You are in love.
With Margaretta.
With Dionisia;
Nor do you shame it, rather cherish it.
It is a choice befitting your high blood;
What you have done, make it as a say
Unto your best desires.
O Lazarello!
Thou givest me poison to recure a wound
Already mortal.
Why this is speedless haste,
I know your fated pleasures would throw up
Their ouer-cloyed receipt; you have been noble
In your brave deeds of arms; who shall boast it,
Your beggars issue? they are Antipathies;
How would it sound to hear poor Margaret say
Her Lord hath brought home honour from the wars:
It would stain your worth to be so vainly boasted.
No, this Lady would multiply your praises with her phrase,
Lest Dionisa say that her Antonio
Won the palm of victory, then you are throned,
And music gracing the solemnity.
One word confutes thee, ever into silence,
I am married.
A mistake in private, who knows that?
Margaretta,
And myself, besides a thousand witnesses within
Quit you those, and who dares speak it else?
Who dares not speak a truth.
Dares not, who dares?
What danger is more great than to speak truth?
If poor ones durst speak plain of great men's faults,
There needed no libelling.
I will choke freedom;
O what a bed of snakes struggle within me.
Tush, they are but worms, and I will give thee seed and reasons
To destroy them; you are married.
A good physician;
Thou killest me quickly to haste me out of pain.
Tush, I must first draw the corruption forth,
And then apply the healing medicine.
Persuade me to turn Turk, or Moore Mahometan,
For by the lustful laws of Mahomet
I may have three wives more.
And concubines besides, turn Moore?
Do you expect such counsel from your friend?
Wrong me not so, I will show you a Christian way
At least a way dispensed with Christians,
Say you distaste your match, as well you may,
When truth shall be unmasked, and shame walk by,
Bearing a blushing torch to light them both.
Mend then the cause before it take effect,
Annihilate your marriage, that is the cause.
It is private yet, let it be private ever.
Allow your Magaret a pension;
She may be glad to embrace that, it were pride
To embrace you, say she be called your whore
may breed from what is done,
Better her shame than yours; a common thing:
Poor beauties are proud of noble bastardy.
Fearful counsel.
Does your Margaret love you?
Beyond her life.
Good, marry Dionisa, grief kills her, then are you a widower.
Horrible murther, it were less tyranny
To kill at once, than by a lingering poison.
Ha? poison? what white devil prompted that?
Poison, brave, the very change of friendship, the trial
Of a friends love to death, would you make sure
Of a friends constancy, a swift poison will strike it dead.
And it is the easiest way, and may be done
Even in the terms of love, as thus, I drink to you,
Or accept these gloves, the taste; the touch, the sight,
Tush, any sense will take it kindly.
I will hear no more from thee, thou studiest to make worse
A positive bad, by a vild performance.
Ha?
Look yonder, there is an eye speaks better oratory
In very silence, where is poor Margaret now?
O my heart.
Look upon that face; well, you are my friend,
And by that trueloves knot; had I that face
But in reversion after your decease,
I think I should give you physic for it.
Worthy Sir,
My noble father entreats some words with you.
A happy messenger invites me to him,
How shall I quit your pains?
I will take my travel for it Sir.
It is too little.
I think it too much sir,
For I was loth to have travelled thus far, had not
Obedience tide me to it.
You are too quick.
Too quick Sir, why what occasion have I given you
To wish me dead?
I cannot keep this pace with you, Lady,
I will go speak with your father.
I pray stay Sir, I will speak with you myself.
Before your father.
No, here in private by yourself.
I will stop my ears, Madam.
Why, are they running away from your head Sir?
I mean I will seal them up from hearing, Lady.
You may, no doubt they have wax of their own.
Venture thy ears no farther good Lazarelles,
She will endanger them, but Lady now I think on
Speak, is not this your hand?
I have three then it should seem,
For I have two of my own fingering.
This is your letter?
You know my mind then by this time.
If I may be your expositor, Lady, I think I do.
And how do you expound me Sir?
Kind and loving.
Kind and loving: it were a good commendations
For a sow and her pigs.
You ask me the reason why I enquired your age of your father.
It is true Sir, for what have you to do with my age?
I would rather have to do with your youth Lady:
Why, my page?
Fie Madam, you are too apprehensive, too dexterous,
Your wit has two edges I protest.
What a cut would that give to a bold crown.
My crown itches not at that, Lady.
Yet you may scratch it though.
Come, come, your wit is a good one, do not tire it.
Unless it remove out of my head, I must,
For I must tire that.
I think you love me.
You and I may be of two opinions,
I think not so now.
Come, your hand has betrayed you.
Do not you plainly say here, we two should be well matched?
O strange, he steals half a text to uphold
His heresy; but what follows, we should be well matched
At a game of shuttlecock, the meaning is,
For a couple of light headed things we could not be over-matched;
He might have conceited that that could have but said
B to a battler: but come Sir, you have said
Enough to me, will you go speak with my father?
This I will add first, which I will avouch unto
Your fathers face, I love you.
This I will confirm to you,
And to my fathers face, but I will not promise you,
Whether I blush or not, I do not hate you.
I will follow you, yet give me leave ere you go
To give a gratitude unto your lip.
My lips do not stand in the high way to beg
A charity, as open as they appear to you.
You will follow me Sir.
I cannot stay long after.
Soft I am in your debt Sir, did you bestow a kiss on me?
I did so far presume.
Take it again --
So now I am out of your debt, hereafter never fear
To lend freely to one that pays so willingly.
Now Sir, what do you do?
I am dissolving an Enigma.
Let me help you, what is it.
I would fain know
What kind of thing a man's heart is.
Were you never
At Barber Surgeons hall to see a dissection?
I will report it to you, it is a thing framed
With divers corners, and into every corner
A man may entertain a friend, there came
The proverb, a man may love one well, and yet
Retain a friend in a corner.
Tush, it is not
The real heart, but the unseen faculties.
Those I will decipher unto you, for surely
The most part are but ciphers; the heart indeed
For the most part doth keep a better guest
Than himself in him, that is the soul: now the soul
Being a tree, there are divers branches spreading out of it,
As loving affection, suffering sorrows, and the like.
Then Sir, these affections, or sorrows, being but branches,
Are sometimes lopped off, or of themselves wither,
And new shoot in their rooms, As for example;
Your friend dies, there appears sorrow, but it quickly
Withers, then is that branch gone; Again you love a friend;
There affection springs forth, at last you distaste,
Then that branch withers again, and another buds
In his room, shall I give you history to this moral?
No, I can do it myself, o Margaretta.
So she is in the vocative cast already, if she slide
Into the ablative, she is thrush quite out of the number.
I am lost Lazarella.
I shall find you again
In Dionisaes arms.
Must I back slide.
If you can find in your heart, you must.
My heart is
A rebel to me.
Faith all your body
Will be accessory to it, I am a friend.
Come, come, league with your thoughts, you are too nice.
How ill thou speakest of good, how ill of vice?
It is now concluded in me, I will on
I must, although I meet destruction:
Down hill we run, climb upward a slow pace:
Easy descents to hell, steep steps to grace.
Quiet your tongue, or I will take away your liberty,
Know you are under me, and my command.
Quiet my tongue? art officer of hell!
Thou Jailer to the devil, fleshly fiend,
I will waken heaven and earth with my exclaims,
Astonish hell for fear, the fire be doubled
In the due vengeance of my heinous wrong,
My heavy heinous wrong.
Forbear I say: you are a cracked virgin,
And I will bestow the widows alms on you
In charity, if you not hold your tongue.
Worst of humanity, hold thou thy tongue,
Shame thou to speak, my shame enforceth me.
Come, come, my little (what shall I call thee)
For it is now doubtful what thou art; being neither
Maid, wife, nor (saving your reverence) widow.
Ha? Dost spit at me? I will have you spitted for this trick,
And I will turn you as you see, and moreover
I will bast you.
O that I could spit out the spiders bladder,
Or the toads entrails into thee, to take part
And mix with the diseases that thou hearest,
And altogether choke thee, or that my tongue
Were pointed with a fiery Pyramis
To strike thee through, thou bundle of diseases,
The store-house of some shaggy meteor,
Some blazing fire shone over thy fatal birth,
And laid up all her sad effects in thee;
Gouts, aches, dropsies, and a hundred more,
For were not poison to thee natural,
Thy own foul rottenness would strangle thee.
Thou art a looser, and I do consider it,
Thou hast lost a maidenhead, a shrewd crack:
A flaw that will hardly be soarderd again;
Some there be that can pass away these counterfeits
For currant, as brass money may be taken
For silver, yet it can never be the same,
Nor restored to his first purity, this I consider;
And bear, (but presume not too much to trouble
The poole of my patience, it may rise foul) it may.
O that thine eyes were worth the plucking out,
Or thy base heart, the labour I should take
In rending up thy bosom; I should take
A vault to poison me (detested wretch)
The hangman's man, basest degree of baseness,
Thou livest upon the lees and dregs of lust,
Thy soul is a hired hackney towards hell,
O Iulianus, my much honoured father,
How is thy simple faith deluded now?
Thou hadst not so much thought of ill in thee,
To breed a bad opinion of a villain,
Tyrant, and reposure, whilst thou art winning
Renown and honour from Spaines enemies,
Spaine has dishonoured and imprisoned me:
Thou understandest not this, unless the winds
Upon their fleeting convey bear it thee;
Some gentle vision tell thee in thy sleeps,
And heaven instruct thee with a waking faith,
True to believe thy slumbers, boyle out my blood,
And at the briny limbeck of mine eyes
Distill my faculties, alone I will tell
My sorrows unto heaven, my curse to hell:
And there I will mix that wretch, from thence they rise,
O whilst I look on him, I loath mine eyes.
But that I have some kinder purpose, I would not
Be thus baited: I am given to the flesh as well
As the king my Master, I have some hope to taste
This dish after time; but it is yet too hot for me,
It will cool, and then I will draw my blade, and have
A flash at it: this woman's two-edged tongue,
And this burthen of flesh that I bear about me,
Hath made me so heavy, I must take a nap.
Cob, boy, Cob, page.
Here Sir.
There is something gone
Into my ears that troubles my brain, blow in
Some music to fetch it out again.
The best I can, my Lord.
And hark you, having done, ascend the Turret
And see if you can discover his Majesty
Coming to the Castle: this hour he appointed
For his recreation, if you do, descend,
And give me warning.
I will.

stage.l: A song within. Lo. falls asleepe.

sp.l: So I have lulled my Lord asleep,
I see he takes my music heavily,
Therefore I will sing no more: now to my Turret
To see if the king come, now he may take him napping.
There is no resting place within a prison
To make my sorrows less by recounting:
I throw them forth, but empty none at all;
Ha, asleep? Aye, security can sleep,
Grief is a true watchman: how the devil snores?
There is hell within him, and, what a hideous noise
The fiends do make; o had I a murdering heart,
I could with his office beat out his brains.
But I have better thoughts; these keys may give me
My release from prison: Can I think
Of better release, no; I will not delay it,
I will keep back my sins from multitudes,
And I may fly for safety to my father.
There is divers ways, heaven instruct the privatest,
And best for my escape: fare ill, not well,
Thou and thy lustful Master: from all but one,
This key now frees me. O! that I bear about,
Which none but mercies key can deliver out.
My Lord, I spy the king coming privately
By himself, my Lord, one were as good attempt
To wake a watchman at three o'clock in the morning,
My Lord, lend me your keys if you will not stir yourself:
Methinks he should wake himself with snoring, but it may be
The more noise makes him sleep the sounder; the best is,
I take it, the king has a private key to let in himself;
If he have, he will do his own work himself, and my Lord
For this time shall be an innocent pander,
In this act of sleep a harmless husband may be so
To his own wife; It is as I guest, he is come
In of himself.
Where is your Master?
He is here
In his private meditations, my Liege.
He was ever heavy, where is Iacinta?
Safe enough,
My Liege, she struck my Lord into these damps
With the very music of her tongue, but they were all discords.
Command her hither, her father sends me word,
He has a noble fortune to bring home
Conquest and royal captives; I shall not well
Requite him: therefore I must now be heedful
What I return, how the villain snores!
Sleep on Sir, your sin will be the less, in being
My bawd. Now where is she?
Alas my Lord,
I have been --
Been imp, where have you been?
Seeking about all the corners in the Castle
For Iacinta.
Why, is she to seek slave?
I can neither hear nor see her
Rogue, thou neither seest, nor hearest more if I see not her:
I will go seek better, my Liege. I doubt some legerdemain,
But if I find not her within, I know the way out.
You dormouse, baby of ??fisty, bundle of security,
Awake Rogue, pocks of your heavy flesh, hast thou no soul?
Minion, I will clog your heels with irons for this,
Will you not let me rest by you?
Mischief ope your eye-lids block, image.
I will tell the king, and he shall tickle you for this.
Sir death, I will tickle you for this, loggerhead, where is Iacinta?
O my Liege, is it your Majesty, I beseech you pardon me:
These after dinner-naps are the repasts to my body.
Diseases devour your body, where is Iacinta?
Safe, safe, my Liege, my keys, where be my keys,
Saw you my keys, my Liege?
Confirmed, she has the keys and is fled the castle:
Dog, hell-hound, thou shalt be my foot-ball, slave
I will drag this hateful lump into his grave.
Nay but my Lord, I protest by mine honour,,
And the office I hold about you, I left them by me.
When I went to sleep, and my first dream told me
They were there still. My boy, my Cob, saw you my Cob, my Liege?
Dogs worry you both; search slave in every angle,
Send pursuit after her, if thou returnest her not,,
Thou shalt curse thy being.
If she be not above steeples,
Nor beneath hell, I will find her, for so high
And low I can reach and dive, as heavy as I am.
If she escape us, and once reach her father,
Now in his height of honour, we know not how
He may receive his wrongs, nor the event,
We will command him distant from the Court,
And his prisoners sent to us; And this shall haste
Before her possible speed, if she scape:
We will threaten his heads loss, if he deny them,
Those that do wrong, had need keep safety by them.

stage.l: Enter Margaretta and Fydella the Moore.

sp.l: O that some striking air had blasted me
Before this poison entered at mine ears;
Married?
Madam, sweet Madam.
Madam! prithee mock me not, nor guard my folly
With such a linsey wolsey ornament.
Madam, is the mad dame, and thence mad woman:
Define it so and I will borrow still
That little of my store. A coat of tissue
If a fool wears it, is but a fools coat.
Such are my trappings, o for time that is gone,
Equality, o sweet equality.
Born under Libra, thou hast both right hands,
Without advantage, or priority.
Base ones made big by beauty are but slaves,
Their Lords never truly bed but in their graves.
Ha? a dangerous conceit; call my brother Fidella.
Then let me counsel you, know he is open,
Plain, and rustical, and altered from his first condition,
your purpose is, let it not appear to him.
Prithee be gone, and call him.
Am I despised so soon? wedlock unjust,
Unequal nuptials are not love, but lust:
Come back past time, o it is a fruitless call,
I may repent, but find no help at all.
Now I forestall thee heaven ere I begin,
Forgive me, I must act some a heinous sin,
I must now be changed.
Lady sister, did your Madamship
Send for my worship?
I did send for you brother.
You may entreat me.
I hope so, I have a letter
To my Lord (brother) containing so much love
And secrecy, as I would trust none willingly
But yourself for the delivery.
A letter sister!
I would not have you to take me for a Carrier,
Or a Porter to carry words, or letters more
Than it pleases me, yet in the way of a Nuntius,
Partly Ambassador, or so, I will
Travel for your sake.
Look you, this is all, brother.
Is this all sister?
Unless you will add another:
Commends by word of mouth.
By word of mouth?
It was not well spoken sister.
Why brother?
Why what words are there, but words of the mouth?
Except it be words of the tail, which would sound but ill
In my Lord brothers ears: for words behind
A man's back are but wind, you know that.
But be most careful in the delivery, I entreat you brother;
You know our wedding is only known to us,
A thing concealed from wide mouthed rumour, then should you
Find him in company with Nobles of his own rank.
Tush, I can smell the rankest of them all.
Say amongst Ladies you should find him sporting
Dancing, kissing, or any such like wantonness,
Take heed your rude approach does not move him to any distaste.
O my own sister, my nose is a little more akin to you
Now than ever it was; you would have me be an informer
Of unlawful games, as Ticktack, whipper ginny, in and in.
No trust me brother, only to instruct you I speak;
For the least disparagement should chance to him
His pleasure forbidding it, would be a death to me.
Well sister, here is my hand, and my heart is
Here about me too, but I would be loath to bring him
Forth to witness, but I will be very careful.
You undo me else brother.
Fa, do ye think me for
A fool or your brother (sister)
Do not think
But at your return I shall be very thankful.
As for that, it is sufficient your Ladyship is my sister;
o ye little amiable rogue you, a good face is a good
dowry, I see sometimes; when we two tumbled both in a
belly together, little did our mother think which should
have been the Madam; I might have been cut the tother
way i'faith, if it had pleased the sisters three, if the Mid-wife
had but known my mind when I was born; I had
been two stone lighter; but much good do thee with thy
good fortunes, farewell honourable flesh and blood, I will
deliver to my noble brother, pretty trim Lady, I think we
are eyed alike, fare thee well, I cannot choose but see thee as
long as I look upon thee.
Effect thy own content, paper and ink,
And then thou bringest the work into my hands.
Fudella.
Madam.
Thou lovest me Fudella.
Do you make a question of it Lady?
No, I rather
Speak it as acknowledgement, suppose I went
In the right noble way, to meet my foe
In the field, wouldst be my second.
To my second life, Madam.
I do intend no such viragoes part,
But in shape, a danger to thee far more worse,
But when it is done, the spacious world shall have to understand,
Spite of the low condition of my birth,
High spirits may be lodged in humble earth.
Sad still!
I am as I was ever Lady,
Full of retired thoughts.
You draw these backward
Should be coming on, and meet in nuptial pleasures.
All strive to be their own Physicians (Lady)
We know what is best and fittest to be done,
But who can follow it?
Till the disease be known
In vain it were to study remedy,
Pray what is your cause of sadness?
I have none, Lady.
Why are you not merry then?
You must find fault with my complexion for it,
Nature, perhaps, has not compounded me
Of equal portions; yet you discover
Diseases outward, I not feele within,
Methinks I am merry.
No, I have heard you sigh so violent,
They have waked my slumbers with you in bed,
One gust following another, as you would breath
Out all your air together, there must be cause.
I know not how to win your good belief, Lady,
But if you will trust me; Lazarello come hither.
A murrain on the carrier brought me hither, I shall sit
the worse this two days, but I think I have requited his
sides for it; Now to my letter, pat i'faith, here is my noble
brother; hum, I have a pestilent Lady to my sister, she told
me I should find him amongst Ladies, if she had said Lady
she had guest singular well i'faith, I will carry it as well as
I can for my honourable brothers credit.
Fie, that is a lame excuse, you won not honour
Equal with your will, myself from the Castle saw you,
Most nobly do, I saw you, uphorse three brave opposers,
You killed and captived many enemies.
Nay now sweet Lady
You make too strict an inquisition,
Men emulate in honour for the best.
Who would be second that can foremost be;
For this a man may wrangle with his fate,
And grieve and envy at another's fortunes.
Hum, hum, hum.
See you yon fellow.
Waft him hence good Lazarello, I am undone else,
Look here Dionisia, here is a jewel,
I never showed thee yet.
It is a very pretty one,
Shall I have it?
With all my heart sweet.
He gives me aim, I am three bows too short,
I will come up nearer next time.
When does the Army
March hence, Antonio?
Some three days hence
I must prepare to go:
I will go with you Antonio.
By no means sweet, I will send for thee
With more harmonious music.
Indeed I must.
Come, come, indeed you shall not.
He will not off Sir.
A mischief carry him.
No! shall I have no notice taken of me!
I will begin in another tone with you Hum, hum, hum,
There was a Nobleman of Spaine, Lady, Lady,
That went abroad, and came not again
To his poor Lady.
O cruel age, when one proud brother, Lady, Lady,
Shall scorn to look upon another,
Of his poor Lady.
How now, what fellow is this?
No man's fellow here, Lady, yet a good fellow too
In place where.
Who? this fellow, Lady? he that knows not him,
Knows not a man of mirth, this Doctor I tell you
Gives as good cure for the melancholy
As the best Empiric in Spaine,
whatever he be.
I would he would practise on Antonio then
Troth Madam it is a good plot, please you to walk
I will man you to the Castle, leave them together,
It is an equal match, if he make him not merry,
He will most terribly trouble his melancholy.
He will make me more sad I fear.
I had rather stay and partake some mirth.
I am no woman's fool (sweet Lady) it is two trades
in Sivill, as your man's Taylor, and your woman's Taylor:
So your Lords fool, and your Ladies fool, I am for the
tongue, not for the bauble.
Well Antonio, I will leave you, and sirrah make him merry,
And I will reward thee:
If I cannot make him merry, I know who can.
Who I prithee?
It will out.
Why my -- you can Lady.
Now you jest too broad sirrah.
That is woman's jesting, Madam.
I was afraid he would have named his sister.
I will make bold to be covered, brother thou knowest
O brother.
Look thee there is black and white for thee from
the little honourable rascal my sister, and a thousand commendations
too without book, which I was bid to tell
thee by rote, if thou canst read and hear all at once.
Yes I can.
There is honourable bones abreeding, my sister is
the peevishest piece of Ladies flesh grown of late, we have
good sport at it to see her vex and fret, she boxes me as
familiarly as if I were her Cobbler, for talking to her, an unnatural
varlet, to strike her own flesh and blood, but I
bear with her for thy sake.
I thank you for it, brother;
Nay, she cuts her lace, and eats raw fruit too, what
salad do you think she longed for the other day?
I know not:
For a what do call them? those long upright things
that grow a yard above the ground; o Cuckoo pintle
roots, but I got her her belly full at last.
So it was well.
But the best jest was, she bit her shoemaker by the
ear as he was drawing on her shoes; and another time her
Taylor for girding her too straight, he had a long nose, but
she did so pinch his bill; what, hast thou good news brother?
Very good brother, all I read are well.
Yes faith brother, we are in health, and drink to
thine sometimes.
Brother, I would have your swift return.
It was my sisters charge, she thinks of long things,
poor heart.
I cannot give you the entertainment I would brother,
but I pray you let this provide for you.
This is Hostess, Tapster, Chamberlain, and all, brother.
In the morning early my letter shall be ready
for you.
I will lie in my boots all night, but I will be ready
as soon as your letter Bonos nochos, mi frater.
Stay brother, one thing I must ask you,
And pray you tell me, What is your thought of me,
Finding me in a Ladies company?
O brother, I would not have you think you have
a fool to your kindred, what? I understand these toys,
there are fowl, and there are fish, there are wagtails, and
there are Mermaids.
Of what sort do you think she is?
O brother, definitions and distinctions! fie on
them, come, I know flesh and blood will be sporting. If
I were a married man myself, I would not always be at
home. I would hawk, and hunt, and ride, there are divers
members in one body, there are flesh days, and there are
fish days, a man must not always eat one sort of meat.
I see you are a wag brother.
Always let a married man get his own children
at home if he can, if he have a bit abroad for procreation
or so --
Well good night brother, I pray hold a good opinion
of me.
O Sir, I can wink with one eye like a gunner, shall
I make my sister sick of the yellow Jaundice? no, thought
is free, whatsoever I speak, I will say nothing; Vale, valete,
valete, valetote.
I can dissemble mirth no longer;
O my afflicted soul, wert thou capable
Of separation, thou wouldst now be sent
Into a thousand pieces: Lazarello.
Now Sir, you are full of news I am sure.
Heavy and froward news: where is Dionisia?
At distance enough in the Castle; you may speak.
I am discovered, Margaretta knows of this
Her wrong, and my disloyalty.
It was no mystery,
And must be found, but how does she bear it.
Better than her birth,
As well as my addition to her, nobly,
And if her hand does not belie her heart,
She is glad that I have found an equal liking.
She has done as becomes her.
Yet with this request,
That I would not forsake her utterly,
But sometimes see her, it is articled too,
That twice a week she would have my fellowship
By night, and private stealths, the which obtained,
She would lose the name of wife, and never shame
To be called my Concubine.
Aye, this is well,
Fine light pageant work, but now sure building,
This gilds a while, but will at length
wash off again;
This roof must be raised upon a sounder groundsill;
Give me your free bosom, you have one heart, and two ways,
Which may have the better part freely.
My conscience
And my affection war about this quarrel,
My conscience faith the first, but my affection,
The second.
So then, you should
Love Margaretta, but do love Dionisia.
My heart is triangled, two points Dionisiaes,
And that downwards Margarett, and that is the smallest.
I thank you for this free delivery:
You seal your friendship to me, now let me build,
I have it, I will rid your griefs at once, will you
But give consent.
To any fair condition.
No worse than Margarets request to you,
Or very little, return your letter, that
You will satisfy all her desire, appoint
Your first nights approach, and privately.
Night cannot hide it ever.
But hear me,
You shall not go, I will supply your place,
Not to blemish, but to preserve your honour
Command your entertainments, so secret be,
As that no lights may lead you to your chamber,
Let me alone to counterfeit for once,
And once shall serve for all, if it but take,
And that she bed with me, not for the act,
For there your honour must be weighed, but company,
Shall serve the turn, then rise I and proclaim
Both our luxurious sins; how dares she then
Claim any part in you?
It is a strange extreme.
Ulcers must have corrosives to eat, not ??kind,
Extremes must have extremes to cope withal,
It will not yield else.
I like it, and allow it,
It is more than water that must fight with wild fire.
This passage shall be instantly prepared
With some of my wearing, brought as near myself
As art can make, this Ring to strengthen it,
I could subtract a third from my estate
To heal her injury, and quite blot out
That taints mine honour, being voiced
It must be cured; pardon heaven and Margaret,
There is an innate falling from what is good,
Which nothing can repair in us but our blood.

stage.l: Enter Iulianus with a letter, and Piamentelli.

sp.l: THat I should ten leagues be in scorn removed
From Court unto my country house! for what?
It is very strange; know you the cause?
Not I, my Lord.
I cry you mercy Sir, and my king mercy,
And I beshrew my thoughts for being troubled.
I know the cause myself, his grace is wise,
For seeing me o a Pyramis of honour,
So eye-able to the world, the talking slaves,
The multitude in their loud bellowing voices,
Might add so much to me Sir, as might dim
His own proper glory, for such weak eyes see
The present object, nothing to come, or past,
He gives me safety in it, and indeed
Himself much worth and honour, for Sir, what honour
Can subjects have, but is their kings own right.
Due as their Crowns, he is royally wise in it,
I do applaud it highly, and obey it.
Your prisoners must be sent him too my Lord.
Ha? my prisoners? that goes somewhat further,
Sir, I beseech you this day entertain
Yourself into our Camp, you are nobly welcome,
The kings health shall go round the Army too
This very night we will answer and confirm
What he commands.
Tomorrow I must return.
You shall, meantime I pray be merry with us:
Commanded from the Court and my prisoners sent for!
It is strange, o my forgetful memory?
I did not ask how my Iacinta fared:
But she forgets too, minds not me her father,
We will mix them both together, but my prisoners!
Sir, here is a woman (forced by some tide of sorrow)
With tears entreats your pity, and to see you.
If any soldier has done violence to her,
Beyond our military discipline,
Death shall divide him from us: Fetch her in.
I have myself a daughter, on whose face
But thinking, I must needs be pitiful.
And when I have told my conquest to my king,
My poor girl then shall know, how for her sake
I did one pious act; is this the creature?
Yes, my Lord, and a sad one.
Leave us: a sad one?
The down-cast look, calls up compassion in me,
A Coarse going to the grate looks not more deadly,
Why kneelest thou? art thou wronged by any soldier?
Rise, for this honour is not due to me.
Hast not a tongue to read thy sorrows out?
This book I understand not.
O my dear father!
Thy father? who has wronged him?
A great Commander.
Under me?
Above you.
Above me? who is above a General?
None but the General of all Spaines Armies,
And that is the king, king Rodericke, he is all goodness.
He cannot wrong thy father.
What was Tarquin?
A king, and yet a reposure.
Such a sin
Was in those days a monster, now it is common.
Prithee be plain.
Have not you Sir, a daughter?
If I have not, I am the wretchedest man
That this day lives: for all the wealth I have
Lives in that child.
O for your daughters sake then hear my woes.
Rise then, and speak them.
No, let me kneel still,
Such a resemblance of a daughters duty,
Will make you mindful a fathers love:
For such my injuries must exact from you,
As you would, for your own.
And so they do.
For whilst I see thee kneeling, I think of my Iacinta.
Say your Iacinta then (chaste as the Rose)
Coming on sweetly in the Springing bud,
And never felt heat, to spread the Summer sweet:
But to increase and multiply it more,
Did to itself keep in its own perfume
Say that some rapine hand had plucked the bloom,
Iacinta like that flower, and ravished her,
Defiling her white lawn of chastity,
With ugly blacks of lust; what would you do?
O it is too hard a question to resolve,
Without a solemn council held within
Of man's best understanding faculties:
There must be love, and fatherhood, and grief,
And rage, and many passions, and they must all
Beget a thing called vengeance; but they must sit upon it.
Say this were done by him that carried
The fairest seeming face of friendship to yourself.
We should fall out.
Would you in such a case respect degrees?
I know not that.
Say he were noble.
Impossible: the act is ignoble, the Bee can breed
No poison, though it suck the juice of hemlock.
Say a king should do it were the act less done
By the greater power, does Majesty extenuate a crime?
Augments it rather.
Say then that Rodericke, your king and Master,
To quit the honours you are bringing home,
Had ravished your Iacinta.
Who has sent
A fury in this foul-fair shape to vex me?
I have seen that face methinks, yet know it not:
How darest thou speak this treason, against my king?
Durst any man in the world, bring me this lie.
By this, had been in hell, Rodericke a Tarquin?
Yes, and thy daughter (had she done her part)
Should be the second Lucrece: view me well,
I am Iacinta.
Ha?
The king my reposure.
The king thy reposure! o unkingly sound:
He dares not sure, yet in thy sullied eyes
I read a Tragic story.
O noble friends,
Our wars are ended, are they not?
They are Sir.
But Spaine has now begun a civil war,
And to confound me only: see you my daughter?
She sounds the Trumpet, which draws forth my sword
To be revenged.
On whom? speak loud your wrongs,
Digest your choler into temperance:
Give your considerate thoughts the upper hand,
In your hot passions it will assuage the swelling
Of your big heart; if you have injuries done you,
Revenge them, and we second you.
Father, dear father.
Daughter, dear daughter.
Why do you kneel to me Sir?
To ask thee pardon that I did beget thee,
I brought thee to a shame stains all the way
Twixt earth and Acheron: not all the clouds
(The skies large canopy) could they drown the Seas
With a perpetual inundation,
Can wash it ever out, leave me I pray.
His fighting passions will be over anon,
And all will be at peace.
Best in thy judgment,
We wake him with the sight of his won honours:
Call up the army, and let them present
His prisoners him, such a sight as that
Will brooke no sorrow near it.
It was a good Doctor that prescribed that physic
I will be your patient Sir, show me my soldiers,
And my new honours won, I will truly weigh them,
With my full griefs, they may perhaps overcome.
Why now there is hope of his recovery.
Iacinta welcome, thou art my child still,
No forced stain of lust can alienate
Our consanguinity.
Dear Father,
Recollect your noble spirits, conquer grief,
The manly way: you have brave foes subdued,
Then let no female passions thus overwhelm you.
Mistake me not, my child, I am not mad,
Nor must be idle; for it were more fit,
(if I could purchase more) I had more wit,
To help in these designs, I am grown old:
Yet I have found more strength within this arm,
Than without proof I durst have boasted of.
Rodericke thou king of monsters couldst thou do this?
And for thy lust confine me from the Court,
There is reason in thy shame; thou shouldest not see me.
Ha! they come Iacinta, they come, hark, hark,
Now thou shalt see what cause I have given my king:

stage.l: Enter Antonio with the Affrican king, and other

sp.l: Stand, pray stand all, deliver me my prisoners:
So it is well, wondrous well, I have no friends
But these my enemies, yet welcome brave Moors,
With you I will parley; first I defy you all.
How?
I am a vowed foe to your King, to Roderique.
How Iulianus?
Nay we fear you not, here is our whole army,
Yet we are strong enough from fear or flight.
Make us understand a reason Iulianus,
If for disloyalty reason may be given
Of this your language.
Be you my Judges whom I make my foes?
Was my power placed above my mercy, or mercy
Above my power? went they not hand in hand?
Ever most nobly.
Ever, ever.
Why, then should Roderique do this base deed?
You do distract us Sir, beseech you name it.
Behold this child of mine, this only mine,
I had a daughter, be she is ravished now.
Ravished?
Yes, by Roderique, by lustful, tyrant, Roderique:
O most abhorred deed!
Join with me noble Spaniards in Revenge.
We will.
Have I your hearts?
Our lives shall seal it.
Then Princely Mullymumen, here I free thee,
And all thy valiant Moors: Wilt thou call back
Thy scattered forces, and incorporate
Their strengths with mine, and with me march through Spaine,
Sharpening thy sword, with vengeance for my wrongs?
Most willingly, to bind me faster to thee
Plight me thy ravished daughter to my wife,
And thou shalt see my indignation fly
On wings of Thunder.
O my second hell,
A Christians arms embrace an infidel?
I will not compel her heart, woo, win and wed her:
Forced has she been too much, -- My honoured friends,
What We all thought to be born home in Triumph,
Must now be seen there in a Funeral.
Wracked Honour being chief Mourner; here is the Hearse
Which we will all follow; -- Roderique we come,
To give thy lust a scourge, thy life a doom.

stage.l: A bed discovered, on it Lazarello, as Antonio: Enter Margaretta

sp.l: Sleeps he Fydella?
Slumberingly Madam; he is not yet in his dead sleep.
It is now his dying, anon comes his dead sleep.
For never shall he wake, until the world
Hath Phœnix-like been hid in his own ashes,
Fydella, take my strength into thine arms,
And play the cruel executioner,
As I will first instruct thee.
I am so far
From shrinking, Madam, that I will gladly be
The Prologue to Antonios Tragedy.
Antonios Tragedy! that very Name
Should strike even sparks of pity from the flint:
Antonio? husband Antonio.
Remember there is another owes that Name.
Aye, that is the poison kills me; shall a strumpet
(For she is no better) rob me of a treasure
So dear to me as he was; yet her I pardon:
The master-thief lies here, and he must die for it:
All mercy hence I banish, Justice look down
To see a woman's vengeance; thus I begin,
And follow thousand thus, now I am in,
Nothing shall pull me back.
O, o.
He has passage yet for breath.
Here is remedy for that, pull Fydella.
He would speak it seems.
Never; his tongue betrayed me once, I will
No more listen my temptations; hear he shall
Awhile, and that but deafly: Antonio,
I was your wife, Lordly Antonio,
And in that balance equalled with yourself,
I was your handmaid, and you might have trod
On my humility, I had kissed your feet,
But with disdain thou trampledest on my throat,
As I do now on thine, and will deface
What nature built for honour, not deceit:
Our wedding was in private, so our divorce,
Yet shall have as free and open blazon
As a truth-speaking goodness; O my Fydella,
Thou little instrument of my revenge,
I would not have thee (for thy duty) lost.
There is gold, hie thee to safety, fare thee well.
I must never see thee more,
this place will be --
Not too hot for me Madam; my complexion
Is natural to it: good fortunes follow you;
If I might counsel you, I would conceal it:
If you can fly, do not betray yourself.
Fie, prithee away, thou wilt mar all the glory,
Conceal the deed? even to the bended brow
Of the stern Judge, I will speak; and call for justice,
Proud of my glorious vengeance, I will smile
Upon my dreadful Executioner:
It was that was first enacted in my breast,
She should not dare to kill, that dares not die,
It is needy mischief, and he is basely bent
That dares do ill, yet fear the punishment.
SOme music.
Music Sir! it is all untuned,
Remember your proud enemies approach,
And your unreadiness to entertain them.
If all be set upon a careless hazard,
What shall care do there?
Rouse you like a Lion,
And fright this heard of Foxes, Wolves, and Bears,
From daring to come near you: a Kings eye
Has Magical charms in it to bind treason down,
They fight like thieves for spoil, you for your own:
O Piamentelli, there is within my bosom,
An army of Furies mustered, worse than those
Which follow Iulianus: Conscience beats
The Drum of horror up.
For what! a Maidenhead!
Pray be yourself, and justify the act,
Stand on your guard, and royalize the fact
By your own dispensation.
Go call our friends together, if we have none,
Hire them with double pay, ourself will search
And break those dangerous doors which have so long
Kept Spaine in childish ignorance.
O good my Lord,
Forbear, there is fatal prophesies forbid you.
There is fatal fooleries; tell me of prophesies!
Shall fear affright me? no; upon my life
It is hidden treasure kept for needful hours,
And now it is come; it is gold must purchase soldiers;
Shall I not seek it then? alone I will break
Ope those forbidden doors, go muster men.
This I dread more than all our enemies,
If good proceed from this, no Magic Art
Shall fright me.
Or good, or bad, I will throw the dice myself,
And take the chance that falls; thou art the first.
Hell wakens, yet I will on, twenty at least
I must pass through before I break the spell,
If this door thither lead, I will enter hell.

stage.l: Thunder and Lightning. Enter Roderique again

sp.l: So now I am entered to the fatal chamber,
Show now thy full effects; ha? what sight is this?

stage.l: Enter Iulianus, Moore, Iacinta, Antonio, Alonzo,

sp.l: It is holiday in hell, the fiends are loose,
I have enfranchised you, thank me Devils;
Was this the fatal incantation
That here was locked so many fearful ages,
And was it decreed for me to dislocate?
Fire consume you geomantic Devils,
Where borrowed you those bodies, you damned chives?
In your own shapes you are not visible,
Or are you yet but fancies imaginary?
What is he that me presents? I have not lent
My carcass forth, I am not sleeping now,
And my soul strayed forth, I am my real self,
Must I be captived by a traitor so?
Devil thou playest me false; undiademed?
And such a sooty fiend inherit me?
Iacinta, too, that she-curse, must she have part?
Kneeling to them, here is a solemnity
In the Devils name; go reign in Sulphur, or in
Some frozen Labyrinth; this Kingdom is mine:
Thou there that me personatest, draw forth thy sword,
And brandish it against hell, I will show thee how.
What Magic binds me? what furies hold mine arm,
Piamentelli, Avilla, none succour me?
What ails you Sir?
My foes are come upon me.
Coming they are, but yet a league distant, Sir,
S'wounds they are come, and have been here with me.
Traitorous Iulianus, and his ravished daughter,
An army of Moors, of Turks and infidels.
Your fancies trouble you, they are but coming,
Too near in that, make up to your soldiers,
Full twenty thousand now will follow you and more.
The Moore is acoming, and the devil too that must
Succeed me in my last monarchy, take arms and fight,
The fiends shall know thy have not played me right.
O for a private place to be hanged in; when all
hope is gone, welcome despair; which way soever the
day goes, I am sure this is my way; If the King overcome,
I shall be hanged for Iacintaes escape, if she rise, I fall in
recompense of her wrongs. All my grief is, I want an
heir to have my purse and clothes, one that would take
the pains for me, an honest hangman were now as good
a companion as I would desire to meet with, I have lived
a Lord, and I would be loath to die an executioner.
Murder is come to light; O sister how hast thou
overthrown our honourable house before it was well covered,
o ambitious sister, half a share in a Lord would
not content thee, thou would have all or none, now thou
hast none, for thou hast killed thy Lord and husband.
I was a Lord, although a bawdy Lord:
I was a Lords brother, although a bawdy Lords brother.
O Lechery, how hast thou puffed me up and undone
me.
O Lechery, thou hast battened me awhile, and then
spoiled me.
Ha? what art thou?
Partly honourable, partly miserable.
Give me thy hand.
Give me thy halter then.
Art thou a hangman then?
Aye, and a mad one, but now I droop, and am ready
to drop into the budget.
Look here is work for thee, here is clothes, and
here is money, would thou take the pains to hang me?
I have lived a Lords brother, and would be loath to
die a hangman.
Do not desire to die, live till thou diest of thine
own accord.
It is my desire, but I want a cord of mine own,
prithee lend me thine.
Let me persuade thee to be charitable to thyself,
spare thyself, and hang me, I have been a Pander, knowest
thou what a Pander is?
In brief a knave; more at large thus;
He is a thing that is poor,
He waits upon a whore,
When she is sick, he is sore,
In the streets he goes before,
At the chamber waits at door,
All his life a runs on the score,
This I know, and know no more.
All this I will add to it,
He wears long locks,
And villainous socks,
Many nights in the stocks,
Endures some knocks,
And a many of mocks,
Eats reversions of cocks,
Yet lies in the flocks,
Thrives by the smocks,
And dies with the pox.
