All this I have been, and now desire to be hanged for it.
What hast thou there?
A hundred marks, besides leases, and lands which I
have wickedly gotten, all which I will bestow on thee, if
thou wilt take the pains to hang me.
Hum? my brother is dead, and there is no way to
raise our house again but by
ready money, or credit; the
hangman many times mounts above his betters; well I
will hang, but my conscience bears me witness, it is not
for any good will I bear unto thee, nor for any wrong
that I know thou hast committed; but innocently for thy
land, thy leases, thy clothes, and thy money. And so
come along with to me the next tree, where thou shalt
hang till thou art dead, and stink above ground.
With all my heart, my guts, my lights, my liver,
and my lungs.

stage.l: Alarum, Excursions. Enter Roderique and Piamentelli.

sp.l: Fly, fly my Lord.
With what wings?
With wings of speed,
Your foes, Sir, conquer, and your soldiers bleed,
The barbarous Moore is titled by your name,
The Spanish King; therefore your safest speed
Will be to Biscany, there you may find
New friends, new safety, and new kingly minds.
There is no friendship where there is no power,
I must crave now, o poverty most poor,
To beg of them received mine alms, before.
I have defended them:
They will you relieve.
I will make the proof: what do you call the man
Whose prowess in that rightful victory
Against the Moors did so much honour win?
Antonio.
He was, and is, and may be, but not long,
This poisoned Iulianus has battered him.
Thou art my subject still Piamentelli.
Whilst I Piamentelli.
Wert thou gone,
I then might boast, I were a King alone,
For but thyself I do not know one subject,
Then subjects all, since you will not let me die,
I will seek a weary life in Biscany.
Thou mutable piece of nature, dost thou fly me?
Thou art frightful to me.
I shall be more frightful,
If thou repel a proffered arm of love,
There will rebound a hate blacker in Art
Than in similitude; forget me not,
Have not I chased thy wronger from his ground,
And my triumphant self thy conqueror?
I am thy King.
I will fear thee then:
Not love me?
The word is poisoned in thy very tongue,
Love thee? as I would love any reposure.
Thy father shall repent.
He must, and will,
That ere he freed a captive infidel.
Look for a vengeance.
Yes, some barbarous one,
It is natural to thee, base African,
Thine inside is blacker than thy sooty skin;
O Iulianus, what hast thou done? thou hast scaped
The raging Lion, to wrestle with a Dragon,
He would have slain with a majestic gripe,
But this with venom; better had been thy fate
By him to fall, than thus by such a hell-hound.

stage.l: Enter Moore and Soldiers, with Iulianus.

sp.l: Bring forth that traitor; seize that lustful whore.
What wilt thou monster?
Anything that is monstrous.
Reward a traitor.
Traitor?
Be thine own judge,
What art thou but thy Kings, and Kingdoms ruin?
Was it thy hopes, that ever I should trust thee?
Traitors are poisoned arrows drawn to the head,
Which we shoot home at mischief, being struck dead,
Then let the arrow be consumed in fire:
Hast not betrayed thy King and Countrey basely
For thee (ingrateful, villainous Moore) I have,
I have deserved to die, but not by thee,
And I beseech thee, bloody Tyrant, hasten
My punishment.
That boon is easily granted.
It is now full glory to thee, to strike home
Set the black character of death upon me,
Give me a sentence horrid as thyself art,
Speak in thy barbarous language, thy last doom,
A tyrants Axe sends me to a blessed home.
Pluck out his eyes, and her exclaiming tongue,
She shall in silent sorrow then lead him,
Her eyes shall be his stars.
O spare her tyrant,
By her offence and wrong thou hast aspired,
Then tread not on her virtues, it is enough
That I do suffer for the good I did
To set thy captived foot above my head:
O spare my child.
Entreat for me? forbear Sir,
Either be you dumb, or let him not hear,
I shall have mental prayers left for heaven,
Fuller effectual than this tongue can utter,
And for the author of my wrongs and sin,
I shall have hasty curses left within.

stage.l: Enter Margaretta with the body of Lazarello

sp.l: O Justice, justice, thou that fillest the throne
O sovereign Justice, thou art a severe one,
Give me thy sharpest rigour.
Against whom?
Myself, the murderess of my valiant husband.
More fruits of Christians.
Yes, and see, here is more,
Antonios ghost! murdered by me, yet livest thou?
Revenge and jealousy misled thy arm,
To kill my friend, (my supposed friend) not me,
Thou strangledest Lazarello.
O, my hard fate.
My aim was full at thee.
End thy just hate,
For I am parting from thee; see those two
That wronged thee are both wounded to the death,
With grief she, I by poison lose my breath.
Forgive him, but spare not me.
How came you wounded?
I clap my hands at this your tragedy,
My birth was base, but my revenge flew high.
A noble girl, a lusty stout Virago.
Iulianus, for a wrong done to his daughter,
(The fatal Engine that hath beat down Spaine)
Revolted from his King, and set that Moore up,
Who now insults, being but a captive then,
And cause in honest language I was just
In taxing this revolt of Iulianus,
He bid a soldier kill me, who refusing it,
He himself struck me; life was lent thus long,
But for the cleansing of my conscience:
I feele deaths pangs, forgive me both, and all,
Let my soul rise, although my body fall:
With honour I got honour, this my sin thrives,
Thus falls the wretched husband of two wives.
So, here is a brace of widows now at one windfall,
A wholesome example to all successors;
Let every wise man take heed of two wives,
It is too great odds, I durst be one of the two
Myself should break one of the strongest husbands hearts.
What should I call thee, widow, shall we marry one another now,
And beget Chimeras, I do not think
That ever any one husband dare venture
On us both at once again.
Dost thou play with thunder, or is that thing
Which should supply the place of soul in thee,
Merely fantastical ere thy passions
Such feathered follies, idle gigglotories?
Are these the rites due to a funeral?
Why? hast never seen the sun-shine of a rainy day?
Who does believe a widows tears to be her hearts sorrow?
Are they not then better spared than derided?
Let me see then what thou darest do with wet eyes,
That I dare not answer with a smiling cheek?
What thou darest not second I dare do.
Begin, I will pledge thee,
Thou darest not.
Try me.
Thus then I come to thee Antonio;
Thou didst forsake me living being dead
I will enjoy thy monumental bed.
Aye, hast thou that resolution?
Methinks a woman (as I am) should not out do me,
I must die one day, and as good this day as another,
Whereabouts is my heart, I think all over my body,
I am all heart, and therefore cannot miss,
Some creatures die singing, why not I merrily,
Make me room Antonio and Margaretta,
We will all tumble in one bed together,
I will lie as close as she on thy left side,
And have as many kisses too, that is my bargain;
My sins are all upon thy conscience,
But I forgive thee, and heaven be the Clarke to it,
My soul will have free passage, my body I bequeath
To thee Antonio, I am your wife,
And will come to bed to you, thus I make unready,
Thus I lie down, thus kiss, and this embrace
I will ever keep, I am weary now with play,
I needs must sleep for ever:
Excellent pastime.
It is night with me for ever, where is this tyrant?
Turn me but to him, and from these darkened eyes
I shall discover his Cymerian face,
For though all is dark, yet still that is visible,
And nothing else to me; see rancorous villain,
Look what a bloody pageant thou hast made;
I borrow eyes to guide me of my child,
And her I will lend a tongue to curse thee with.
Ha, ha, ha.
Thou laughest at misery.
It is well, thou givest a grave unto my sorrows.
Yet wherefore shouldest thou glory in it? this work
Is none of thine, it is heavens merciful justice,
For thou art but the executioner,
The master hangman, and those ministers
That did these bloody ravishments upon us,
Thy second slaves, and yet I more deserve,
I was a traitor to my lawful King,
And though my wrongs incited on my rage,
I had no warrant signed for my revenge,
It is the peoples sins that makes tyrants Kings,
And such was mine for thee, now I obey,
But my affliction teaches me too late:
On bloody ropemaker, finish up my fate.
The rest shall noble be, I will not confine
Nor give thee living in captivity,
Thy body shall enjoy the general prison,
But thy soul set free.
Thou art good in that, and noble.
Nay it shall nobler be in the performance,
Give him weapons, thou art a soldier,
And shalt end so; I will be thy opposite,
With odds of eyes, but not of arms, I vow,
If thy dark aim hit in my face, I will stand,
And die with thee, if not, fall by my hand.
Thou wilt hurt my penitence, for I shall bless
All the ill deeds that I have done for thee,
In this so noble end.
Be prepared then.
One thing more of thee, be a prophet to me first,
For thou knowest what shall become of my poor Iacinta,
What end to her is fated.
Before thy end thou shalt know it.
O let it noble be, and honourable;
Her life has had too many strokes of sorrows,
O let her end be sparing.
It shall be noble too.
I beg for her that has no tongue to beg,
And what remains in my faint yielding breath,
Shall all be spent in blessings over thee:
Farewell Iacinta, take my latest blessing,
I know thy soul returns a thanks to me,
Make haste to overtake me, if thou beest stayed,
Think of Cleopatra and Brutus wife,
There is many ways to end a weary life.
Come Sir, I stand before you.
Thus I come,
Thy death I will venture, but receive mine own,
So, I have my doom, and I have hit too.
Ha, ha, ha.
Laughest then? I am deluded then.
O bloody homicide, thou hast slain thy daughter.
False villain, hast thou then so mocked my woes,
To make me fatal butcher of my child?
Was she the target to defend thy body?
Forgive me my Iacinta, it was in me
An innocent act of blood, but tyranny
In that black monster: it is not much ill,
Better my hand than a worse arm should spill
Thy guiltless life; what art thou going yet?
Thy warm blood cools, my sun begins to set,
Nature shrinks backward to her former forms,
Our souls climb stars; whilst these descend to worms
See tyrant, from thy further strokes we fly,
Heaven do thy will, I will not cursing die.
So, now we live beholding unto none
Upon this stayre we do ascend our throne,
Give us our title.
Long live Mullimumen King of Spaine.
Your silence it confirms, take hence their bodies,
Give them to Christians, and let them bestow
What ceremonious funerals they please
We must pursue the flying Roderique,
All must be ours, we will have no Kingdom sharer.
Let Chroniclers write, here we begin our reign,
